title: 105_hr4431
content: The "HIV Partner Protection Act" is cited as the short title. It amends the Public Health Service Act to include a section on partner notification for HIV health care services. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" amends the Public Health Service Act to require states to implement partner notification programs for individuals with HIV disease. States must also ensure that health entities report positive HIV test results to the state public health officer confidentially. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates states to have partner notification programs for individuals with HIV. Health entities must confidentially report positive test results to the state public health officer, including necessary information for the program. The program ensures partners are informed of exposure to HIV without revealing the infected individual's identity. Counseling and testing for HIV, including transmission information, are provided to partners and infected individuals. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates counseling, testing, and referrals for HIV-infected individuals and their partners. Counseling includes information on transmission, prevention, and therapeutic measures. Referrals for appropriate services are provided. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" mandates counseling, testing, and referrals for HIV-infected individuals and their partners. Referrals are provided to partners and infected individuals. Notifications are given in person, with no penalties for non-cooperation or errors in reporting. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" ensures no penalties for errors in reporting under the program and allows the State to provide notifications without the consent of the infected individual involved. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" allows States to provide notifications without the infected individual's consent and prohibits insurers from penalizing individuals who undergo HIV testing. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" prohibits insurers from penalizing individuals solely based on HIV testing and defines terms like 'infected individual' and 'partner'. The "HIV Partner Protection Act" defines the term 'partner' to include spouses, sexual partners, and individuals exposed to HIV disease. Certain states have delayed applicability of the act until fiscal year 2001. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide grants to States to assist with the costs of implementing partner notification programs for HIV. $10,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually from 2000 to 2004 for this purpose.
